I purchased this tablet for my 8 y.o. daughter 2 years ago for Christmas, it has been stepped on and dropped (including down our long staircase) repeatedly and it's still working fantastic although there is a small crack in the corner on the right side of the Home button (So I would recommend buying a screen protector if it's for a younger child) The battery holds a charge for several hours even though she tends to have multiple apps and windows open at the same time including youtube and games and doesn't seem to lag or slow it down at all, we make several 9+ hour trips out of state and she is on it for the whole trip without charging it. The 8 GB storage seems small but I can say that it holds ALOT, The only problem we have ever had was the USB chord was bad when we purchased it so it didn't charge, but we called Samsung and they sent us a new one at no cost to us.

Pros:  It has an SD Card slot for added storage,  It has Bluetooth so your able to transfer music files, ect. from other devices. It has Wireless Internet so if you have Hotspot you can share your internet data to the tablet and  have internet anytime, anywhere. And the Battery Life is exceptional. Plus an added bonus is that almost all Samsung devices are compatible, which means you can save important files including Contacts and Numbers, Text Messages, Pictures and Phone Call Log Records by sharing them over to other Samsung tablets, phones or laptops by downloading Smart Switch free from Play Store.

Cons: None in almost 3 years...Would recommend this tablet to everyone.

First off, if you found this review helpful in your decision-making, please click on the helpful button so this review may help others in their decision-making process.

Purchased as a christmas gift for my father. I was not looking for anything specific on the internal specs, just something for someone that is new to this technology. My attention was drawn to this tablet because it is from a reputable brand and known model (Samsung Galaxy), its very light (dad has shoulder problems), and could withstand a few drops (kid friendly, but not a kid OS). Very good for basic operation (web surfing, netflix) as well as a decent amount of games (texas holdem, FPS games, solitare, etc.) and the screen gives a very good, clear picture. Full battery lasts about 5-6 hours with non-stop gaming. Did not expect my dad to know about skype, so unfortunately, its hard for him to use with no front facing camera. Storage is expandable, if needed, with a slot for a micro SD card. All in all, this is a very good starter tablet and a good tablet to give to a school-aged child (ages 5-10). I highly recommend this tablet for basic operation, just not for skype.

This tablet runs android 4.4.4, which was nice, when it was released in 2013. This device was released in 2016... It can't and won't be updated. Many apps in the app store simply do not show up because they are no longer compatible with such an old version of Android. This was bought for my kid and even Minecraft isn't compatible.

Let me explain the scam this really is. At the time of the tablet's release in 2016, Android 6.0.1 was available, a month after it's release, 7.0 was available. Hardware wise, this tablet is 100% up to the task of running version 6 and probably version 7 with no issue.

The absolutely only possible reason to release this tablet with version 4.4.4 in 2016, is so that it is obsolete as soon as it's bought. I don't mean something new always comes out to make your tech obsolete... You can literally buy a 2013 tablet and have a more up to date tablet than this because all tablets from other major manufacturers release at least one or two updates.

Samsung is a garbage company and what they've done here is just flat out disrespectful to it's customers.

It would be nice if the product description clearly stated that the OS is no longer supported and you might not be able to install some favorite apps.

Generally, it does it's job as a tablet.  However, that 1 GB of RAM can cause a bit of choke/lag while using the tablet to access intensive content.  It also grows a bit warm with long-term usage.

To get to the meat of what my review is on about, I field-tested this tablet as a tether-dependent device for Pokmon GO, in the context of passively gaining items/dust/EXP for my alternate account whilst I actively catch on my main phone.  My provider at the time of these tests was T-Mobile, and my Phone was the first Google Pixel.

I will also note that, if you do get this device, you will not be able to download Pokmon GO from the Google Play store, but instead from a APK mirror site.  The reason why is that the Tab E Lite only has 1 GB of RAM vs. the minimum requirement to download being 2 GB.  What comes below is not the fault of Niantic or Samsung, but rather a summary of what to expect if you are using this device as a cheaper option to other, beefier tablets.

For my urban field test, I used Philadelphia- specifically, Center City and around Spruce Street Harbor Park.  Immediately after hopping off the Regional Rail @ Jefferson Station, it was having issues loading up the game.  Granted, the station was underground, where you are bound to have poor reception.  However, my phone loaded up just fine then.  I take my devices above ground and find that the device can now load the game, but my movement is not registering on the tablet.  Again, the phone is fine.  The tablet begins to finally register movement once I leave the general area of City Hall.  I presume the tall skyscrapers in the city severely impacted the GPS locator on the Tablet, as they had also done the same to my Pixel on previous visits. Operation is generally very choppy, once more a testament to how I am running a game that takes 2 GB RAM on a device with just 1 GB RAM.  Catching Raid Pokmon is very difficult, with a half second delay on the screen to your own interactions.  Battery Life was roughly 4 hours of usage under those conditions (weather was dry and cool, about ~45 degrees Fahrenheit)

For my suburban field test, I used the campus of Arcadia University, where the reception is generally excellent.  Both the tablet and the phone function properly and with relatively smooth operation.  The tablet grows slightly choppy after the 3rd hour, but nothing like the test in Philly.  Raiding is passable.  Choppiness can be remedied with a quick reboot/cooldown period of 15 minutes.  Weather conditions applied to this test was about the same as the Philadelphia one, but I did have a light drizzle.  Battery lasted 5 and a half hours.  Rain is not kind to touchscreen accuracy.

All said and done, this device is so-so for Pokmon GO, but only if you're willing to deal with sub-par operation, and if you play in suburban and rural areas (assuming the rural areas have decent coverage from your provider).

The first Samsung tablet we bought was 5 years ago, I assumed they had started making them better since them. We had S3 phones that were just as terrible, and upgraded to S6 phones, and the S6 have had no charger port problems, so I thought they figured out how to make them strong enough for daily use. Besides the disappointment of the broken charger port, charging in general took a very long time. Now I'm forced to decide; another Samsung? Another fire (which are just terrible with port problems and a limited app store), or just suck it up and buy another iPad, the only product that lasts more than half a year. After having bought this product in February and having nothing to show for it by August, I don't see me wasting my money on another Samsung.

We bought this tab to replace my daughter's 2015 Christmas gift of a Samsung Galaxy Tab 4. In many ways, it's very similar! It's size and capabilities are very comparable to what she had. On the plus side, it seems to hold a charge much longer and it was more affordable than her Galaxy Tab 4. On the negative side, the graphics resolution isn't as crisp, and there is no front camera. She's 9, though, so she either doesn't notice or doesn't care about the differences. I do, and I was disappointed in those small downgrades, even though they were both clearly spelled out from the item description.

She mainly uses her tab for watching YouTube videos,  reading ebooks, and playing games. So far, this tab has been able to handle all of these tasks. We added a microSD card for added storage, as the device storage is laughably small. All in all, it has been a very good value for the price paid, but I wouldn't recommend this tablet to anyone other than a kid, only because the quality of the experience suffers with the lower price point.

My real criteria for rating tablets, aside from speed, is durability.  I have confidence that Samsung devices will be durable, and avoid problems like failing to charge six months afterwards --- problems I associate with no-name devices.  Time will tell, and I will update the review if I have any problems.

One tip.  I find that hockey stick tape is an effective and cheap way to create a bumper guard for tablets.  Just tape it around the sides until you get a reasonably thick bumper, being careful not to cover the ports that you need.  It's cheap, and if you take care doing it, it doesn't look bad.  You don't want to spend 70 bucks for a tabet, and then shell out another 20-30 bucks for a sleeve.  But if you don't cover the device, it's almost certain to break on you.

After using an iPhone and iPad for a few years, I decided to try this Samsung tablet.  The Samsung Galaxy Tab E-Lite has several things going for it and a few things against it, especially when compared to the iPad.

First a few pros. The price - at $120, this is a great tablet.  If you don't have the money to shell out for the ever-popular iPad, the Samsung will most likely give you everything you are looking for in a tablet.  Did I mention its relatively inexpensive?  Memory card slot: here is where Apple can take a lesson from Samsung  I want to be able to expand my tablets memory capacity.  With this tablet, I can do that with a Micro-SD card.  Setup was pretty simple.  I connected my Google account to the tablet and in a few minutes I was exploring my apps options in the Google Play Store.

Now a few cons.  I find that its not near as responsive as my iPhone or iPad.  If you're not picky about responsiveness, you won't mind as much.  But going from an Apple product to this Samsung was like taking a step back.  It was rather frustrating.  Also frustrating was that some of the controls are simply not intuitive.

Of most concern to me are the poor parental controls.  My kids will probably be the ones to use this tablet the most for videos and games.  Ive set up some parental controls to limit what they can download, but so far Ive been able to go into the Play store and download free apps without ever having to put a password in.  Short of disconnecting the wifi from the tablet, I still don't know if Im doing something wrong.  When it comes to parental controls, Apple has Samsung beat hands down.

Overall this is a good tablet especially for the price.  If this is for kids and you are wanting good parental controls, you might look elsewhere or again, disconnect the tablet from any network.

The "Samsung Galaxy Tab E Lite 7-Inch Tablet (8 GB, White)" is a respectable entry level no frills small tablet (7 inch screen).  It is lightweight (less than one lb.), easy to hold and handle, and certainly the price point is favorable to those new to tablets.  It can do most functions casual tablet users desire such as web browse, read ebooks, handle email, play games, and take photos with the rear facing camera.  It is easy to navigate and to access and download apps.

It has 1G of ram and 8G of ROM (really not much), operates at 1.3 GHz., and comes with a 7" display screen with 1024x600 resolution.  It functions on an Android 4.4 KitKat operating system.  It is Wi-Fi and Bluetooth enabled and comes with a microSD slot to increase memory up to 32G.  It requires a Lithium ion battery (enclosed) claiming a nine hour life per charge but mine has not lived up to that level.

If you are a longtime tablet user or, like me, have used iPads for years, adjust your expectations for this tablet.  It is slower and less responsive than tablets I am used to and I find the browser to be a bit clumsy for this product.  It has no front facing camera which may disappoint some younger users.  And as mentioned, storage space is very limited at 8G.  All in all, an effective entry level tablet for the budget minded that would be attractive to the casual, part time user or for a youngster getting acclimated to electronic products.  3.5 stars.

For a small, budget tablet, this is pretty good.  The only other tablet I have owned is an iPad that I have used heavily for about three years.  The Tab E Lite not only has a smaller screen (obviously, at 7 inches), it is slower and less responsive than my now aging iPad.  Still, it works, has a decent feel to it, and let's be honest, using Chrome on a tablet is better than Safari.

Two other points worth considering.  The battery drains without use at a faster rate than an iPad.  That's a minor annoyance.  The thing that gets me is the inclusion of a microSD port.  If you are going to put another port on a tablet, why not a USB port, or maybe HDMI?  With HDMI, I could hook this thing up to my projector and not have a chord running across the room.  With a USB port, well, even more options. MicroSD?  Really?

Those are minor complaints given the price tag, though.  For a small, budget tablet, this thing gets the job done.  It lives on the coffee table, and if you want a budget device to keep around the coffee table just to have it there, this is a solid choice.
